 I will say that immoral behavior hides behind religion, however, and even reaches into its scriptures to justify it. I also find a substantial amount of people, who desire to find the truth in religion, soon become bogged down in it, mostly because they are unwilling to go that extra step – to rid themselves of ego. Sometimes it manifests in anger and total disappointment, opening them up for “enlightenment” to the point they claim there is no God or Supreme Being and that we are all alone. That is where religion, by proxy, causes violence and immorality, IMO. I am not saying that the unreligious are rogues and knaves – far from it. It amounts to those that pervert a religion or a specific religious teaching that I am referring to.

I don't have much doubt that the rules of various religions are extensive and absolute and that some of the failings in religion can be attributed to the people that "follow" these rules. However, even if we assume everyone could follow these rules to the letter, you would still have to question the morality of some of the doctrines that were formulated so long ago.
 
 For example, there are various quotes from christian scriptures referring to justified acts of murder, smiting etc. If there is disagreement on this, I'm sure I can list a few. By todays standards, these are not justified penalties or punishments for failure to comply to an ancient code. These are simply suggestions that immoral behaviour can be accepted in various circumstances, even when it contradicts teachings from the same school of thought. Whether it is the failing of an individual or not in this case is largely irrelevant, since it is in the framework of their documented belief system.
 
 Having said that, a religion is more than a set of written commandments. It is the way a collective group manages their belief and subculture. Accepting immoral behaviour in their ranks without taking action or expelling members, is effectively promoting these activities.
